So, in short: This book lies about what it is, and sucks at what it actually tries to do. BTW: Blackburn is a legit scientist with some serious cred to her name. But she's also a new-agy sort with a weird enthusiasm for 'mindfulness'. Plenty of pretty badass scientists get equally worked up in making mirror neurons into some kind of god neuron, up to an including being the literal seat of the human soul. . .soo. . .I mean. . .A bad book doesn't make her a bad scientist, but neither does being a good scientist make this a good book. This is a bad, bad book.

I wish I liked the book, but I didn't, even though I think it's useful.What is particularly great in this book is that it is indeed backed up by a lot of research, and I mean a lot, these are two prominent researchers, one having won a Nobel Prize. So take their words.What is not so great is that the book is actually formatted as a kind of self-help book. The book could provide some pretty concrete tools dealing with mental and health problems, from simple exercise routine, some meditation/breathing practice, to types of diet. Great to know the mechanism explaining why these advice work too, in the powerful telomere indeed proven in research for both short-term and long-term effects. Now, it would be useful for super newbies, I think, like me who is faintly aware that I need to be more concerned about my health but do not know where to start. For people who are already engaging in/starting healthy lifestyle, this book doesn't provide anything new except for more reference and another clear scientific mechanism. For many others, they would not be able to get interested, since the book's writing is just... so banal. The two authors take turns talking in first voice, which is weird and not cohesive to me. The illustrative stories are so boring. I feel like they could not get connected to the readers, common people of different backgrounds, perhaps because of the way they do research that tends to be abstract and distant, in the lab and in theory, or because of their own background being white upper middle class, highly educated maybe. I couldn't find any passage that I'm actually moved. Have they ever been through similar difficulties, severe stresses, diseases, accidents, or been raised in difficult situations, in poverty? The answer is likely to be no. I don't hate them for that, they try to show compassion but readers can definitely tell there is a gap there.If the book had been written not as a self-help but more of a general nonfic, focusing on discoveries, details, challenges, future of research related to Telomere, mayyy be it would be better since the compassion property is not that important. I said `maybe' because as in any field, you need some kinds of drama in the academia circle to spice things up, and I have no idea whether this is the case for Telomere.

The subtitle is a screaming clue as to where your expectations should be set before reading. I clearly missed it, or was a little too optimistic, because this ended up a self-help book with roughly 30% of the inspiring science woven in.The first few chapters are great with the setup of the doctors' lifelong work and research, and explained in accessible terms what telomeres are and their importance. The rest, however, was a mix between the "mays" (there may be an association, something may be attributed, etc.), chapters of things that shorten telomeres and in turn your life (stress, bad diet, risky behaviors, poor exercise), and some generalized practical information on how to address these areas in your life. None of these are revelatory and all are things we already know.I have an issue with their crutch for illustrating stress, using "mothers of autistic children" repeatedly to the point that you start to wonder if the authors have a strange beef with autistic people. Insert "mothers of gay children" or "mothers of colorblind children" and see how badly it reads. Instead of placing the blame on our society's lack of inclusion for people with differences, it reads as: don't be autistic, look at the terrible things you've done to mothers.The other objection that stands out is the tip-toe dance around the impacts of sugar and processed foods on health. In the chapter on being overweight, the authors indicate overall fatness was not a detriment to one's health, it's the presence of belly fat that needs to be addressed as it's a critical metabolic indicator of health. The authors lamented the folly of dieting, how it does not offer any lasting results, in fact, making you worse off than if you hadn't dieted in the first place (no objection with this part, study after study shows this). Yet they inserted just a short snippet stating that sugar and refined carbohydrates are the source of the metabolic problems that come with the belly fat. Not anywhere close to the level of detail they provided in other chapters that illustrate the impact of the various stressors. It's bewildering to say the least.I don't disagree with the recommendations, but they're generalized things we already know.This would have been such a great book if they'd stripped the self-help out and allowed the authors to expand on the research they've done going back to the 70s.

Self-help book couched as a scientific breakthroughIf you're looking for a book to motivate you to take up new whole-body lifestylepractices to reduce stress, then this is for you. If you're looking forscientific breakthroughs in our understanding of longevity and novel changes youcan make to improve your own health, you won't find that here. The good news isthat the lifestyle changes proposed in this book are by no means controversial.You likely already know what they are: eat healthfully and decrease stress (bothpsychological and physiological, which turn out to be very intertwined).My main complaint is that the book promises to establish a strong causal connection between telomere length and overall health and a direct way to optimize this, but only manages to establish telomere length as a marker of cumulative bodily stress and makes recommendations on how to reduce stress in general. The fact that high levels of telomerase do not always result in increased telomere length and that longer telomeres can actually be detrimental in some cases (by leading to cancer or promoting cell growth of undesirable systems) show that telomeres are not the entire story (or at least that we do not understand how telomeres work fully enough to make recommendations strictly on this basis). In this sense, the book overpromises and under-delivers.Other nits (in no particular order):- The first section reads as an autobiographical recounting of the authors’ achievements but is not very actionable- Sloppy editing and style: “I (Liz)” and “I (Elissa)” sprinkled throughout - Not nearly enough citations for some of the strong causal claims the authors make- Renewal lab sections often lack citations and have no connection to earlier material in the chapterDespite the negative points, I think this book can be a useful tool in improving overall mental health (and that it does a good job of showing that this does affect other aspects of physical health). In particular, the advice on resilient thinking is likely actionable and effective. Similarly, the dieting advice is actionable and likely effective (based on other reading I’ve done, but not based on evidence provided by this book) though incomplete.Overall, some may find this book useful, but it didn’t quite align with my expectations.

This is an excellent introduction into the world of telomeres. They are the tiny bits of DNA that keep your chromosomes from unraveling. The length of your telomeres can directly measure your biological age and by extension your state of overall health.I liked that it is a joint effort of a molecular biologist and a health psychologist as everything is linked. There are studies after studies that show how your mind affects your overall health & vice versa. Here the molecular science is matched up to external forces to demonstrate that your thoughts & actions do change your cells. I have seen this concept repeated in many books over the last year. Fat communicates to the brain, as does your gut biome, which in turn take direction from the brain.The book is filled with ways you can help your body keep your telomere lengths as long as possible. Part of this is diet, exercise and mindset. If you want a super good way of thinking about eating better, think about how each meal choice is helping or hurting your telomeres. They can tolerate short term shocks, but not chronic behaviors. Even if you start at 50, they can still heal. The message is the same as many other books on overall health. Get enough sleep, exercise regularly, eat whole fresh food and have a solid social net around you. It is not a fluke that the highest concentration of centurions in the world is in Okinawa. There, the people practice exactly that and live past 100.I have seen the results of behavior that hastens the shortening of telomeres along with behavior that kept them long. A group of my relatives decided that the best thing for themselves was to smoke and drink to excess. Plus they added their always angry attitude and bad food to make it even worse. They all died in their early 60’s of multiple cancers. Pictures of them in their 50’s look like they are 80. No joke. Another group of relatives are currently in their mid-90’s & not living in a senior home. They live in their own house and take care of themselves. Still sharp, though a little hard of hearing. Their only vices have been coffee and being in the sun for hours on end. From this book the underlying reason is telomere length. From their studies and evidence, I can see why.

Overall I thought that book was quite well done in describing and outlining the mechanism through which some well established environmental and internal circumstances can lead to a change in our health. I thought the book was well organized in first describing what telomeres were then, touching on the importance of the telomere and concluding with ways that individuals can address their telomeres and a discussion of the different factors that impact the length of telomeres. In addition I felt that for the most part the book had a very optimistic and practical bent, covering how it is never too late to start to make worthwhile changes in your lifestyle, and that while you may have deterministically bad circumstances there are still ways to try to recover through individual effort. As an individual connected to the academic world I also appreciated the subdued language used by the author when describing the results that they found always tempered by the limitations of the studies that were used but still trying as best they could to outline in a way that a non-specialist could understand the main results of the research being conducted. With a good outline of the methodology and the logic underlying the authors assertion of a causal effect between different lifestyle choices/circumstances and telomere related metrics, allowing the reader to reach their own conclusions on the persuasiveness of the studies as well. The one mechanism that I thought was the most important and revolutionary personally was the importance of mindfullness physiologically, since I had previously believed that this was a mental phenomenon that could support mental health but did not have the type of impact on cell biology that I now know exists and will definitely keep in mind moving forward. At times I thought that book could have been a little more concise but in addition to the science I did enjoy the inclusion of personal anecdotes in order to relate the ideas to real people making it easier to relate to the subject matter. Overall this book gave me quite a few ways to improve my life that are directly actionable and a new way to think about why I am making healthy choices in my life and for that I am happy and am glad that I read this book.

If you’ve head about “telomeres,” this book does a great job explaining what they are and why you should care about them. In some ways, the advice is what you’ve been hearing for years - eat healthy foods, exercise regularly, sleep enough, and add in stress-reduction techniques like meditation or Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction. Where this book differs is in making specific recommendations on these categories (and more) and demonstrating how it affects your telomeres. I really like how important they made getting help for anxiety and depression because of its significant effect on telomeres and overall health. Some quibbles - like many self-help books, the recommendations are generally much easier to put into practice if you have a certain degree of privilege. And the authors admit that, discussing how policy makers should address **societal stress reduction** as a public health imperative (it seems stress has the greatest effect on our telomeres). In our current civic climate, that to me seems like something that will have some quarters of the Internet s teaming “SNOWFLAKES!” Additionally, as someone who’s in the midst of a weight-loss regimen, I found the research about the effect of weight loss on metabolism misleading. The book cites a study that looked at contestants from the reality show The Biggest Loser, who were burning 600-700 calories less six years after the show, even after regaining weight. However, when I looked up more details on this, the average metabolic drop for people who’ve lost weight is more like 200 calories less, and may disappear after a year (see this summary of studies https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/w...). I felt like the authors had a dislike of dieting and wanted to find research that supported their conclusions. I think that they should have used the science that they were more familiar with, because discouraging people from losing weight isn’t helpful in a society where 70% of people are likely to be overweight or obese at some point in their lives. Overall, worth a read, and I’m glad to have the paper book to have as a reference for some of the practices I’d like to implement.

I went into this book thinking it was gonna be more science-oriented but I was wrong. The fact that the co-author is a psychologist did seem interesting to me in the beginning because I read this book purely for the genetic aspects and I must admit it was a little disappointing. Genetics does have a deep influence on every field of medicine. Even my Master's degree in Genetics included a paper on psychology. And that's why I decided to finish reading this bookI've always found the science of telomeres interesting and the book provides some great insight into how the cell works and how our choices can affect our life and the process of aging. Although it doesn't really provide any new information on how to live life except from the vantage point of telomeres. Like the fact that eating good food, avoiding stress, good parenting, good relationships, reducing stress, good society, etc etc are pointers towards a longer and healthier life is something I can read in any self-help book. The book gives some really solid tips, I won't lie. Its all-encompassing guide to good living. That is provided you have the money for it, the ability to follow all the suggestions and most of all.. if your genes allow it! I mean you could follow every advice in the book down to a tee and still not live a good life because of things like socio-economic conditions and your inherent genetics. It would probably help those people who really reeeaaaally want a scientific backing on lifestyles choices but other than that I wouldn't recommend this book. Also, stressing about lifestyle choices can also reduce the quality of your life which the book mentions as well, so thanks for that.They have tried to address every aspect of living, pointing out the problems of racism, abuse etc and I do commend them for that. The book has some great sources and references all put together in a handy book and the writers have done an incredible amount of research. There are some nice tips to a better life but like anything too much or too little can be bad and you can follow them if you want you but it all comes down to just trying to live life as best as you possibly can in the current circumstances.

I am not a big reader of self-help books and this book falls into that category, more or less. BUT – this book is different. We have known for years, perhaps centuries, that living in a moderate and rational way will lead to better health, happiness and longer life. It has only been within the last 100 years that science has shown us better ways to accomplish these goals, and now how to measure it quantitatively by measuring telomere length.Telomeres, discovered by author Elizabeth Blackburn, are strings of DNA and polypeptides found on the ends of our chromosomes that buffer the processes of cell division. They are longest at birth and shorten over our lifetimes as “life” takes its toll on us and serve as a reasonably accurate index of overall relative aging. This process of loss can be accelerated by stresses of various sorts, curtailed or even reversed, depending upon whether the stress is moderate or severe. Moderate stress is actually good for us, but severe, repeated, or chronic stress prematurely shortens the telomeres and thus shortens our lives and the happiness that may bring. The process is complex and involves proper nutrition, shielding of toxins, good social and community conditions and attitudes.I liked the book for several reasons. It is well written by THE expert in the field – Blackburn was awarded a Nobel Prize for the discovery – and her frequent collaborator, Elissa Epel. The evidence is laid out in a systematic and understandable way with most of the pertinent and important supporting articles actually referenced in the back so the reader can decide whether the findings are relevant and acceptable science. There are also helpful sections if you would like to put into your own life some of the suggestions for good health found in the book. Last, there are URL references for some of the good ideas.The book is worth reading and re-reading if you want to do your best to see your grandchildren marry and have their own children.

I feel bad giving this book 2 stars, but I had to force myself to read it. It started off strong - lots of biologic science, but developed almost into social science. It appears that they have conducted a very strong systematic review of the literature, but I think they imply a lot more than is known. They do try to highlight this, where the direction of relationships between telomere length and an exposure is unknown (like depression and telomere length), but the book is full of correlations and evidence that "appears" to say...Telomerase is the enzyme responsible for restoring the DNA lost during cell divisions. I thought the did a great job of documenting and explaining the consequences of people without properly functioning telomerase. I was surprised to learn how early their research (1980's) began. I remember when I took genetics in 2004, the books didn't recognize the full potential impact.However, after the first 70 pages, they turn to examining the evidence for lengthening telomeres and increasing telomerase activity. They are extensive and cover as much as they feel confident. This article does a great job of explaining why I tend to be critical of many of their statements: http://slatestarcodex.com/2014/12/12/... - Beware the Man of One Study. I find that most of the people talking about juvenescence state outright that traditional statistical methods of measuring associations can't be applied. They (I'm thinking of Dr. Peter Attia) make the argument (probably correctly) that we won't be able to measure associations in this area as firmly as we would like and will have to rely on what makes sense based on the totality of evidence. Anyway, that later 3/4 of the book is probably helpful, but I'm not sure the correlations are related to causality (as in a healthy diet will result in longer telomeres, maybe people who are willing to eat such foods do so because they have longer telomeres).

It was a decent read and probably would have better if I was less versed on well-bring and optimal lifestyles. The first half was far more interesting to read, as it explained how telomeres and telomerase function in your body and what happens when we cause damage to them. The rest of the book followed what most reputable scientists and nutritionists recommend which is to, eat real foods, stay away from sugar, exercise moderately (although they did say extreme exercise shows no damage to your telomeres unless you have over-exercising fatigue syndrome, which was validating to read), meditate, practice mindfullness, unitask, get 7 hours sleep, stay away from harmful toxins (heavy metals, pesticides, etc...), have a strong support system and an environment you feel safe in, stay postive.....basically do all the things, wvery day, and try not to strees out over them (which is laughable and usually a stressor in itself). The book tried to tell me, like many before it, that I am a pessimist and my telemores are probably short but I am not supposed to let that upset me or stress me out because then my telemores will only be shorter ( read: no pressure just change your personality, forget all past life experience, and look on the bright side quick or you're gonna die sooner). Actually the more I think about this book the less stars I want to give it....

How our lifestyle gets into our cells: Telomeres. Telomeres are the repeating bits at the end of our DNA that protect the DNA during replications. The shorter our telomeres, the older our cells. Older cells don’t work as effectively for thing like fighting off disease. Stress also has a notable impact on telomere length. More stress, shorter telomeres. Or at least more negative impacts of stressful situations, the shorter the telomeres. Our attitude to stress is important. Seeing the situation as a challenge instead of a threat protects our telomeres. Pessimism, especially hostile pessimism has a devastating effect on our telomeres.Telomeres also show our activity level. Endurance exercise and interval training both lengthen telomeres, and improve our immune system and longevity. Healthy eating and good sleep also help our telomeres. And our telomere length at birth is directly related to our parents, especially mothers telomere length when we were conceived. The mental state and health state of parents have a direct, permanent impact on a child. The book summarizes a large number of studies, a good chunk will turn out to be non-replicable, but still a lot of interesting information here. A downside is the book is a bit repetitive and does get a bit far off track on techniques for reducing stress, but worth reading.

I had high hopes for this book and it left a lot to be desired. After a brief introduction on the nature of telomeres and telomerase, which could have gone much deeper, the book devolves into a typical self help, positive psychology lesson covering topics that have been elucidated much better in other books. If you are new to the genre it is a helpful collection of suggestions. If you listen to health and wellness podcasts, read up on current nutritional and biomedical science breakthroughs, are a fan of functional medicine, etc. then the scholarship comes off as pretty light weight i.e. they advocate the Mediterranean Diet - really? That is straight out of the 1990's. Ancel Keys has been getting bashed for years. Why is there no mention of the ketogenic, GAPS, low FODMAP, or bone broth diets? Where are the references to intermittent fasting? They mention the suprachiasmatic nucleus - and somehow never get into the topic of blue light toxicity. Where is the discussion on the toxic effects of EMF exposure? And you don't need cognitive behavioral therapy to get over food cravings. Becoming fat adapted fixes the problem. Overall it's a missed opportunity to make a real contribution which will have to come from future books.

If you aren't familiar with telomeres, or aging research in general, this is a great introduction. The first part of the book is a fairly decent, extremely accessible explanation of how telomeres and telomerase relate to aging. The authors then provide some information about how to hopefully improve the health of your telomeres. So in case it never occurred to you before, if you are currently living like Charlie Sheen, you may want to rein yourself in a bit. Benefits include longer telomeres and looking somewhat less like something the cat dragged in. Your welcome. In all seriousness, though, the book basically rehashes all advice ever given about taking good care of yourself (sleep well, avoid negative stress, and >>ideally<< transform yourself into a middle class white person), and simply calls these things "good for your telomeres" instead of "good for your health."While I'm sure the authors have plenty to say on this topic, they didn't exactly use this book as their opportunity to share it with the rest of us. I would have enjoyed hearing more about current research, and for me the highlight of the book was actually the discussion of telomere disorders and how they affect patients.

Good book and I like the new research around telomeres. I first became interested in telomeres when reading about them with mindfulness practices. Personally, I think the first 10% of the book is all that I needed. In the early section, I loved learning about the health phase of life and the disease phase of life. Learning that I can minimize the disease phase was critical because the last thing I want to do is spend too long in the disease phase of life (...for me, hit me with sickness and then put me in the ground. Make it quick)! There comes a point where health science books seem to reiterate ideas. I have a tendency to start losing interest because conceptually there are three components of long term health: physical health (cardiovascular and muscular), mental health (mindfulness, meditation, engaging in activities that require thinking) and community health (interpersonal and community relationships). If we pay attention to these three forms of health, then we are honoring most of what modern health research suggests. In this book, there appeared to be some deeper understanding of each form of health, including practices that have a greater impact on telomeres. For me, that means continuing cardiovascular health and strengthening my social relationships.

I listened to this book while machine sewing a quilt because I literally could not find a single audio book to check out digitally that was on my to-read list. Errr. Anyway, I thought it was interesting because I love the fascinating science behind it all, and I do find that understanding at a cellular level what's going on in your body IS motivating to eat healthier, sleep more, etc. I read some other reviews that complained that this book had nothing to add to a huge slew of other self-help books, which is most likely true. I usually don't read self-help books though, so I liked the one chapter summation of why sleep is important and another chapter on eating less sugar. And while yes, I already knew those things, again, knowing why at a cellular level and what research was done is motivating, and honestly I don't want to read an entire self-help book on each of the topics discussed. One chapter was plenty. I also liked how the authors provided little "labs" that summed up how you could put the research into practice in your own life. But I had a hard time finishing it after I finished my quilt and overall it was pretty much stuff I already knew (besides the science behind it all--which was surprisingly a small part of the book.)

In honor of my most recent birthday, I decided I wanted to pursue telomere health with greater intention. (Yeah, I know that may sound nerdy.) This is a comprehensive look at achieving healthier telomeres. It goes beyond exercise, and diet, into sleep hygiene, healthy v. unhealthy orientation to stress, chronic anxiety/stress, etc. In this respect, it was a sort of personal checkup for me. Also covered is epigenetics, and the effects of chronic uncontrollable traumatic stress that gets passed from one generation to the next--and even the next. Adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) are referenced here. Suggestions for personal telomere health, and how to help children have better health is included. If you work in a school setting in a high-poverty area, and/or one hit heavily by the opioid crisis, this helps in understanding a lot. It's a useful book for someone who is at yet fairly unfamiliar with the role of trauma, and its effect on physical and mental health and lifetime outcomes. If you are familiar with all that, it's still good in that we get a telomere snapshot of something specific happening inside our bodies. Glad I read it, both professionally, and personally on the occasion of a big birthday year.

The book outlines how telomeres affect our health, health starting at the cellular level. Telomeres are the caps at the end of each strand of DNA that protect our chromosomes, like the plastic tips at the end of shoelaces, and they, like shoelaces, keep the DNA from unraveling and breaking apart. The longer telomeres you have, your DNA won't unravel as fast as someone with shorter telomeres. Longer telomeres = longer life, shorter telomeres = shorter life. The authors describe in detail what contributes to longer or shorter telomeres, which, like many health-based books will tell you, is altered by what you eat, how you handle stress and your general level of emotional intelligence, how much you exercise, how much exposure you have to chemical toxins, your social connections, and what genes were passed to you.I thoroughly enjoyed this book, it went by fast. Though the information on how to improve your telomere health is the same as how to improve your overall physical, mental, and social health that you read in other health books or articles, this research starts at the genetic level, from the ground up.

This book is a combination of science and self-help. It explains the science of telomeres and how the longer your telomeres, the better chance you have of living a long, healthy life. The book includes many questionnaires that allows the reader to estimate his/her telomere health and provides suggestions for making improvements. The book is for a general audience and explains the material in an easy to understand way. Overall, I think the book is very good - a must read for anyone interested in living a healthy lifestyle.I listened to the audio book version. The audio book was fine, but I plan to get an ebook version to go back and look over some of the sections in more detail. Also, I found it tedious to have the narrator read off all the questionnaires and list off web addresses. If I'm on a walk and listening to the book, I'm not in a position to take a questionnaire. I just want to listen to the text portion, then go back later a do the questionnaire. Maybe it would be helpful to just put all the questionnaires at the end in an appendix, at least for the audio version.

The Telomere Effect in a lot of ways was everything I had hoped it would be and in other ways fell extremely short.Pros: I loved how this book approached changing behaviors and habits in a way that makes it feel manageable to change your lifestyle. Some self help books have the tendency to make you feel guilty for eating bad, not exercising, etc. I liked how this book took the perspectives of both a biologist and a psychologist. It gives you two scientific perspectives that are both valuable for telling the full story of telomeres. Cons: This book felt a little too self help for me. I expected more elaboration of experiments and more biomolecular bases in their analyses. However, this book is written for the public, so I understand omitting these forest details. I feel like I expected more of an evolutionary basis for the reason for telomeres, a history of the discovery of telomeres, and more into how long we telomeres can cause certain forms of cancers. I felt like the scientific aspect of this book was cut short. Overall, three stars seems suitable. Interesting enough to keep the reader reading, but not enough to quench the thirst of a scientific mind.

Listened to the audiobook, suitable for x2 speed.Telomeres are like the little caps on your shoelaces, except for your DNA strands. The length of our telomeres help determine how fast our cells age and when they (and we) die, and then we find out that telomeres shorten with every cell division... Are there ways to promote healthy telomere length and potentially slow down their ever-diminishing processes? You bet! This book takes us through fascinating discussions, strategies, and research on just how important these little DNA caps are in our lives.Favourite quotes:Aged cells can cause a vast array of aging diseases."Genes load the gun and environment pulls the trigger." ~ George Bray"How much does aged appearance reflect inner health? ... People who look older have shorter telomeres.""It turns out, the most efficient use of time is to do one thing and to pay full attention to it. This uni-tasking, sometimes termed "flow", is also the most satisfying way to spend moments. We allow ourselves to be content and absorbed."

Telomeres are nucleotide chains at the end of chromosomes. Recent information about these chains has made them a much considered concern/opportunity with scientific, primarily medical and health circles that study human wellness and longevity. Blackburn presents research and its applications to treatment of illness, predictions of longevity, lifestyle, and economic factors. A common starting point of research is the length of telomeres and related characteristics of persons withe longer or shorter lengths (longer is usually better,) societally who has long or short chains, and moves on to what circumstances relate to longer or shorter chains. The research results are detailed and fascinating. (I learned my telomeres may have been shortened by have been a caregiver for many years but also lengthened by now living a low stress life in a supportive and friendly community with lots of trees and flowers.)Blackburn gives suggestions for caring for one's telomeres that are useful but appear to be more from her analysis than from research.

I highly recommend this book to anyone who wishes to learn more about the science of telomeres and about how to improve one’s “healthspan”. With that said, there are many factors that affect our telomeres over which we have little to no control, and some folks will learn that and focus on it and feel discouraged or depressed. After reading this, I better understand how my early life, my mom’s life and choices, and the ACE (Adverse Childhood Events) I experienced have negatively impacted my health outcomes. . . but since there’s nothing I can do about those things, I have enjoyed learning about what I am already doing well and where I can focus my energy to continue to improve my health. Another aspect of this book I am enjoying is the connection the authors point out between lived experience, especially when people live in constant stress and/or oppression, and the effect on telomeres. They are quite blatantly making a call for us to further our efforts toward social justice and equality for everyone.

I read this book thanks to Blinkist.The key message in this book:A singular cellular structure has profound effects on aging. It’s called a telomere and the shorter it gets, the older we feel. By attending to the health of our telomeres through changes in diet and lifestyle, it’s possible to look and feel both younger and healthier.Actionable advice:Set an aging goal and pick an aging role model.Take a moment to imagine a future in which you enjoy telomeres that enable you to live a longer and healthier life as you cross into your 60s and 70s. Then, plan how you’ll spend your days at this ripe age. Consider what exercise you’ll do, what social activities you’ll partake in, where you’ll travel and what books you’ll read.Finally, find an older role model who fits the image of vitality you want to attain at their age. It might be Judi Dench, Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy, or even your own grandfather.

The Telomere Effect: A Revolutionary Approach to Living Younger, Healthier, LongerElizabeth Blackburn, Elissa EpelWe already know that the right kind of diet, moderate exercise, sufficient sleep, the absense of a toxic environment, and the right amount of stress is healthy for us. That's old news.What's new is how the authors, and others, have determined and explained how the above attributes can have a measurable effect on the length of our telomeres, and how that correlates with a healthy, longer life.The authors cite numerous medical and psychological studies that support this view; their explanations are aimed at the general public, and are easy to read and understand. The authors are quick to point out that there are many unknowns in the present state of research, and much more needs to be done.For those of us who have never heard the word "telomere", this is a fast, easy introduction.

The science behind this work sounds very intriguing, perhaps even stunning. Of course, as new as it is, there are likely elements of it that will shortly have to be modified to fit yet newer facts. Get the right amount and kind of sleep, reduce stress, eat right, and come from a good home, and all will be well with your telomeres which will help give your chromosomes the best chance of giving you a long and healthy life. (Telomeres are the ends of your DNA strands that are like the aglets at the end of your shoestrings; keep them nice and long and the replicating of your DNA will proceed smoothly.)My only concrete struggle with the authors, currently, is the health benefits of dairy products and maybe to a degree the "OK-ness" of supplements; both of which I need to run by WFPB folks to see if they've considered this work. But the volume contains much worth considering for one's health in any case.

Spoilers for my book clubers who might read my reviews//I liked this book. Maybe more like a 3.5. There were parts that just strayed away from the science bit, and gave unscience-y examples of how to fix your life. Seems like more studies needed to be done to prove some points better. But I did find it fascinating how just by simply being a pessimist could actually shorten your telomeres. I've been working hard on trying to see more of the bright side. It's hard. Even with meditation, massages, acupuncture, and all the things I feel like I'm constantly fighting (not physically or emotionally) how negative other people can be at times, and how that instantly puts me in an equally glass is half empty space. But I'm trying. And now I have even more of a reason to do so. Thanks science. I may not totally believe you all the time, but this book made things make sense. Fingers crossed it was telling the truth.

4/10 Unfortunately this book follows the example of other pop science books, and takes an interesting subject, and simplifies it until it loses most of its meaning. The book, for all intents and purposes could have been simplified into the following: Telomeres protect your DNA, which slows aging, you should therefore protect your telomeres by practicing good health. Thats it, just be healthy. None of the information on health was "revolutionary" as was touted in the original title, which has thankfully been changed, nor is it "new" as the book now claims. The science, though interesting, was fairly sparse throughout the book, and the authors seemed to confuse correlation and causation in nearly every chapter. Not a terrible book, but for a much better, briefer, and frankly more entertaining description of telomeres, I would recommend episode #502 and #1054 of the Joe Rogan Experience podcast.

The discovery of telomere was the Nobel Prize winning worthy and it explains the secret of living younger, which we all want! Telomearase is the enzyme that replenishes telomeres which protects our DNA and the length of telomeres provides biological basis for mind-body connection. And now we know how to improve and lengthen our telomeres to keep us vital and diseases free! The secret is actually what we already know such as avoid processed foods, exercise, reduce stress, getting good sleep, and building loving relationship. So no surprise there we have just understand the scientific researches to back up what we have known all along… We can change the prospective of our lives, younger and healthier by choosing for well-being life style!“Telomeres do not simply carry out the commands issued by your genetic code. Your telomeres are listening to you. The way you live can in effect, tell your telomeres to speed up the process of cellular aging.”

Insights into the Wonder of Our BodyUntil listening to THE TELOMERE EFFECT, I had never heard of this aspect of health. I found the insights in this book fascinating for personal health and longevity. The information is straightforward and well-told yet important for healthy living. There are many practical things you can do to reduce stress, form new habits and live a more full and healthy life—yet you have to take action based on the scientific evidence. Change is hard no matter what change—but these authors encourage you to take small incremental steps to move your life in a new direction of health. The first key is to get the information in this audio book and listen to it. I knew nothing about telomeres but learned a great deal from THE TELOMERE EFFECT. I highly recommend this interesting audiobook.

Should have been called, "Stress Less, Live Long & Healthy".Another good title, "Psychology & Telomeres: A marriage of health."I had the playback speed set to 215% by the end.The science was interesting, and seemed valid, and the authors always pointed out anything that was not 100% supported by the rigors of the scientific method.But, I got bored with the albeit great psychological exercises. Mindfulness found it's way into this book too. Hell, maybe I should give it a go. I just wish they'd played up the equally useful role of anti-depressant/anxiety medication in solving stress/anxiety for when mind games don't work.Other interesting "marriages" included: exercise & telomeres, and food & telomeres.I wish the whole book was briefer, but it was good information, and I'm better for having "read" (listened) to it.

Whereas this book is informative and the authors are suitably credentialed, I can't honestly claim that I fully believe that targeting telomere length is in any way a key to experiencing a healthier or longer life other than tangentially. Rather, it seems to be the various activities one engages in that happen to also result in lengthening telomeres that contribute to those things. Sometimes.So I listened with an open mind and found the subject interesting (I'd never even heard of telomeres) and am happy to learn from their lists of exercises and surveys that by all measures given I should have preposterously long telomeres already, for whatever good they will do me, I'm not going to be going out to test and explicitly target my telomeres — particularly given that it costs between two and five hundred dollars just to have your telomeres tested.

First half: 4 stars. The science behind telomeres and how they can lengthen and shorten based on as much nurture as nature, is absolutely fascinating. I loved reading through the progression of their discovery, and how it rocked the world of genetics. Second half: 1.5 stars. I was just bored and expecting more. Socioeconomic privilege, exercise, mindfulness, healthy eating, good relationships: we all know these are great for us. The studies demonstrating correlation between advantageous circumstances and telomere length were interesting. The general conclusions weren’t made in such a way as to teach me anything new. Also, each chapter was interspersed with “activity” labs that really took the reader out of the lesson in order to apply it - this would have been better left as a workbook towards the end of the novel.

This is not a science book, it is a thinly veiled self-help book. The science behind telomeres is too new for clear causation to be established. Yet this book would have you believe that the secret to a long life is all about treating your telomeres correctly. While the numerous studies cited throughout the book indicate those with longer telomeres are healthy there isn't strong science presented backing up why that is the case. Most of the advice presented in the book for better health has supporting evidence independent of telomere length, which the authors don't recommend getting tested anyway since their is so much variability and no medically significant comparisons, except in rare genetic diseases. Give this book a pass.

An excellent book to guide you towards better living. All the suggestions made in this book were not something new. Have been hearing it all my life from parents. However, the explanation of how these suggestions affect us biologically has a greater impact. The studies supporting the claims are a good add on. Most of us know the things we need to do, to live a long healthy life. Yet, very few of us take steps to follow it. This book also helps us to inculcate these changes in our daily life, one step at a time. The language followed is very simple and very easy to follow. Some of the things are repeated over and over again in the book. Apart from that, its a great read to make changes in our life for a better living.

I was really interested in the origin of this scientific discovery, and Mrs. Blackburn does a good job telling how she bumped into this amazing, Nobel-worth revelation, by analyzing the infusoria from a pond sample (more precisely the genetic material from a ciliate called Tetrahymena). So Part 1 of the book is amazing and I can't recommend enough if you are interested in the subject.From Part 2 on, the book starts giving you these assessments, so that you can analyze what you are doing today with your life that may be speeding up the shortening of your telomeres. I didn't find this useful nor was interested in any of it. Thus I can't say I finish the book since I ended up losing interest from Part 2 on and saw myself skipping entire chapters that didn't appeal to me.

I really learned a lot from The Telomere Effect. I consider myself to be a relatively healthy person, so I was surprised to discover things that are likely shortening my telomeres. After each chapter, there are exercises and quizzes for self assessment, which is really helpful, and then also steps to take to improve the health of your telomeres. The book is approachable and easy to read. They talk a lot about the studies and science behind it, but it’s not difficult to comprehend. It took me awhile to get through this, mostly only because I wanted to take my time and digest it. I recommend this to anyone who likes to follow advances in health sciences and also if you’re looking to improve your well being.

It's another reason to do the healthy self care stuff like meditate, exercise, get enough sleep, eat nutritious food, create community and emotional support networks. There are ways the book can be a bit gruff: "all you need to do is change your relationship with stress so that it doesn't feel threatening." This makes it feel like it's mostly written to well-off non-marginalized folks, even though a lot of the data is about marginalized folks such as women care-givers. Maybe it's the audio book, but I feel like it could use a little bit more acknowledgement that getting past trauma is difficult.That said, if you're interested in aging and ways of living to prevent chronic stress, it's an interesting book.

I didn't understand it when I heard someone says they read a book that changed their life, didn't quite fathom how one book can really change a life! until I read this book. The way I deal with stress, the way I manage my relations, the way I eat, sleep and exercise are never the same again. A real eye opener, beautifully written, very engaging and so easy to grasp the most complicated processes happening on our bodies. Loved the book and enjoyed reading it. I talk about it in every opportunity I can have and I recommended it to my family, friends and colleagues. I am so looking forward for another book by these two marvelous ladies. Now I need to go and meditate a bit, I take care of my precious telomeres...

Kind of a slog to get through this book and dissapointed to say I didn't personally gain much from it (having read a lot of health books perhaps more than most casual readers). To summarize, long Telomeres are good, short are bad. Live healthy and you will create longer Telomeres. To be healthy follow the usual common sense: More fruits and veggies, less sugar, less refined foods, less meat, don't burn your food, don't eat from plastic, have plants in your house, deal with stress, don't be depressed, have a good upbringing and loving parents, be educated, exercise, have a loving partner, have sex regularly with said partner, have close friends that you can talk to and bond with. [I may have missed a few, but I take it you get the gist].

The discovery about the correlation between telomere length and lifespan (but more importantly: “healthspan” vs “diseasespan”) serves as the foundation of this book. The early chapters about the biology of telomeres are interesting and new to me, but the second half of the book rehashes what most of us already know about healthy living (eg get enough sleep, eat well, reduce stress, etc). The science of telomeres gives us one more affirmation of how to live healthfully, but I don’t think most of us need to read this book to know this. I did appreciate the nomenclature of healthspan and diseasespan as a frame of reference to think about two very different ways that people might live to the same age.

As other readers mentioned, the content of this book is fairly predictable. The author even mentions on multiple occasions that the experimental results were as expected. I think it would be easy to skip this book. It wasn't really what I was expecting and does come off as a generic self help book with telomere ties. I guess I was looking for something akin to Survival of the Sickest, which was fascinating. The one benefit of this book was that I had fallen off the wagon of my healthy lifestyle and had become more sedentary. This book has motivated me to get back to a normal exercise routine and cut out the junk food. So in that regard I think it was a worth while read. It is a good book but in no way revolutionary.

Although we all know that healthier living is better for everyone, the interesting aspect of this book is the effect of better choices at the cellular level. What I appreciate about the viewpoint of the authors is that these good lifestyle and environmental choices make for a longer time in the healthy span of individuals before the disease span begins. It also demonstrates the importance of wholistic living. Depression and poverty are high indicators of earlier heart disease. The urgency of positive change at the personal and social level is demonstrated in a non-shaming way. I wanted to keep “reading.” I listened to this book and I wished I had access to the many PDFs and tests, but I can check out the website to find which ones are there, too.

The topic is of interest to me, and I did appreciate the information provided. The audio book was a long listen for me. The hardcover edition is 416 pages, so pretty long.Had I known there was "Summary, Analysis & Review of Elizabeth Blackburn's and Elissa Epel's the Telomere Effect by Instaread," I might have chosen that approach. It lost detail, squeezing 416 pages down to 24 pages, 4 before the table of contents, but it may have been good enough for my needs. I did find the biology interesting, but didn't really need to get into that much detail.Now I wonder if I will be looking for other Instaread books.

Linus Pauling won the Nobel Prize and went on to many other fields, notably promoting Vitamin C as a miracle drug. He demonstrated that excellent work in one field does not guarantee the same success in another. The Telomere Effect by Blackburn and Epel is another example of a Nobel Prize winner expanding beyond their field of expertise. I imagine this book will join Linus Pauling's Vitamin C books-distinguished author, undistinguished book.If you collect self-help books, you might enjoy this rehash of familiar advice to eat healthy, exercise, and avoid stress.For more: http://1book42day.blogspot.com/2017/1...

Thought this book was helpful and confirmed what I always thought: clean living, eating, and good sleep make for a healthy body. What I didn't expect the book to confirm for me is how fragile we really are and how easily affected we are by every little thing imaginable. Yes, I already knew the most bizarre and seeming unrelated occurrences in life can affect human behavior. What I didn't realize was the toll it took on our physical bodies to the extent it did. This book was an eye opener in that regard. Thank you to the author for making me more aware of my behavior and how that will affect my telomeres. This is food for thought!Abe SurdeAuthor

This books two authors, Elizabeth Blackburn and Elissa Epel, take different approaches to explaining the health effects of telomeres, the bits of DNA that cap chromosomes and regulate lifespan. Blackburn, a Nobel winning scientist, captured my reading attention with clear explanations of what telomeres are and do. Epel provided advice on mindfulness, diet and other factors that can lengthen our telomeres. The scientific parts of the book were fascinating, but the most of Epel's contributions to the topic were just plan encouragements for healthy living, which we hear all the time from many media.

Elizabeth Blackburn won a Nobel prize for her discoveries involving telomeres which can be found the ends of each of our chromosomes. The telomeres protect our chromosomes and when telomeres shorten and wear down, our cells can’t replenish and malfunction. This results in increased risks of major conditions and diseases of aging. According to Blackburn we can do things that can delay or reverse the deterioration of our telomeres. The “things” Blackburn is referring to are healthier lifestyle, exercise, better eating, stress management, meditation. Overall the scientific info on telomeres and telomerase is insightful.

The telomere effect by Drs. Blackburn and Epel is a call to action towards a focus on telomere health. The book provides the reader with the research surrounding telomeres (the caps of chromosomes) and the connection to health span and disease span. Essentially, long telomeres are good for health and short are bad. There is a natural way that telomeres shorten over time but much is impacted by lifestyle choices, mind; and environments factors. Overall, a hefty book that shows one of the main mechanisms of aging and provides molecular proof of our lives impacting our biology. There’s so much there so I encourage you to pick it up and read it.

This was an interesting book with lots of excellent information. I read it more for the tips than for the research, though the research is essential for determining how useful the tips actually are. It is clearly written, well-focused, and informative without being an information dump. The renewal labs at the tend of each chapter may be the most beneficial parts of the book. Most of the tips aren't shocking: eat healthy foods, get sufficient sleep, exercise, and avoid distress while accepting eustress. That said, the research helps to provide a better motivation for making necessary changes in life and helps to illuminate the mechanism through which these things impact overall health.

The book is an extravaganza of medical science. My spouse will not agree it’s a scientific fact, unless the co-writer won a Nobel Prize for her research. The language of the book is pretty simple. I may look for more serious terms and jargons. Telomeres are the tails of our chromosomes which determines our aging pace and when we possibly die. If they are short, we are fragile for death by unhealthy conditions, such as stress, traumas, junk food, alcohol and smoking.The discovery is very promising for aging technologies in future.And better it is, telomeres can be lengthened by choosing a mindful life.

This book does so much more than describe what the Telomere is, which are the protective ends of the chromosome, but also offers useful recommendations about how to care for those protective end, possibly enabling a younger, healthier, and longer life. It was written in an easy to read manner, despite the scientific explanations. Most of the diagrams were not helpful, but maybe because I found them too simple. It was written by Nobel Prize Winner, Elizabeth Blackburn, PhD and Health Psychologist, Elissa Epel, PhD. They were not simply regurgitating what they had read, they did the work. I feel empowered by the information and recommendations these women shared. I recommend this book

This book is a good synthesis on many topics. It explains the "why" behind nutrition, stress reduction, mindfulness, physical activity, mental acuity, and sleep to lead to better health-span outcomes. I deducted one star because this book spent a significant amount of time trying to sell the reader on telomeres while constantly dangling teasers. If you are reading the book I think you are pretty much on board. I deducted a second star because the book did not really advance any of the underlying fields, it simply summed them up. If you have already read on those topics and internalized the lessons, there is not much that you will do differently.

the book is ok; it feels like the rest of the current "scientific self-help" books being published lately and saturating the market. I guess I just got out of it what I've already read and known via Google, personal experience, and observation: living younger, healthier, and longer (notwithstanding being involved in an accident, etc.) is based on your genes + your environment + your own actions (eating healthy v. eating crap, brushing your teeth v. not brushing your teeth, running v. sitting on a couch all day, smoking v. not smoking, etc.). In short, I am glad I read this, but will not read it again.

Starting with an explanation of the neuro-biology of this fairly newly-discovered health-preserving aspect of our DNA, the authors make a broad leap outward, in myriad directions, to inform the reader of the ways to use this information for personal benefits. The content is a verification that sound health advice from various, venerable sources has measurable implications at the cellular level of our body. The authors make frank conclusions from many scientific studies on the subject, offering an informed and motivational recommendation for empowering ourselves with the scientific insights that they share in this work.

Not too bad for a health book. The only thing I remembered is that our body is always listening to us and we have to give it the right signals to keep those telomeres happy :-) So: eat healthy, exercise and keep your stress level low.Also I feel for all the caregivers since in the author's study it was found they have the most stress and have shorter telomeres and hence shorter life span. Hopefully this book will shine a light on caregivers' plight and help them minimize stress in their lives.

Cool book. Haven’t got around to fact checking yet but the data seems legitimate. A lot of the advice given is kind of common sense and what I’ve read in a lot of other books on wellness, but it’s interesting and valuable to see the benefit of such habits on the biomolecular level, which I suppose is the whole point of the book, and some results of the studies did surprise me. All-in-all the book serves its purpose without necessarily saying anything groundbrakingly new in terms of what to do on a day to day basis, but that’s coming from someone who’s read a lot of popular lit on the matter.

Good food for thought on how our daily actions, lifestyles, and life long development can affect the basic building blocks of our physical existence. While I feel most of the recommendations are not particularly earth shattering from what we often hear from health care literature, it does provide some introspection opportunities to determine if we are living our daily lives in the healthiest manner for our cells/DNA. Even if you want to skim the book, you may find a few gems to inspire yourself to change some of your daily habits.

This is a fascinating book that exposes the telomere dimension of health and well-being. A lot of the advice given on promoting healthy telomeres is obvious: eat healthy, exercise, avoid stress, meditate etc. - the telomere angle just adds another layer/reason/motivation to follow the advice. As such, there wasn’t anything really new here, just very good and clear advice on living a healthy and long life. Great book for learning what you’re doing right, areas you need to work on and how to proceed/get started. Also great if you need more convincing for why you need to kick that bad habit.

I started this as a book, and then it was due back at the library, so I got the audiobook (which worked out great with Thanksgiving travel). This isn't the best book to listen to as an audiobook, but that said, I loved the book itself. This is the perfect blend of science but also for mass consumption. The research in this book is valid and easily applicable without being preachy. I may need to go back and read parts of this in the physical copy book later on to refresh my brain, but this is definitely one of the top books I've read in this genre.

I would give this book 3.5 stars, if I could. There was a good review of the science. However, there was a lot that was simplified and perhaps oversimplified. I was also concerned by the tone akin to “live longer if you do this one cool trick.” The short story is that telomere health is supported by exercise and eating whole foods, but it felt like sometimes the authors went a little beyond this. I also do not recommend the audio version of this book. There are too many hyperlinks and quizzes to work effectively as an audiobook.

Ok, so this is written by the people who discovered and have been studying telomeres for decades. Scientists are not typically good at being authors of popular books, and some of that comes through. But you can't quarrel with the underlying argument. After reading this it seems abundantly clear that I don't have much of an excuse to not try a little harder to change things - at least at the margins. I especially appreciated the discussion of the link between mental health and physical health.

This book has great content - there is a lot in here to guide us to living a healthier life without all of the shaming that usually comes with not doing all of those things every day. It's dry though. The doctors did as best they could to make this book interesting by providing relatable and every day situations that most of us face in one form or another to get their point across, but it still took a little more effort to finish. Pretty normal for a science/study heavy book. Good information with a good message.

i would have enjoyed this book more if i only read the first part. the expanding field of telomere is incredibly interesting and is shining light in a lot of issues that need more attention in healthcare - all surrounding the notion that lifestyle and social factors play a huge role in determining our wellbeing, even on a biological level. with that said, this book places far too much emphasis on telomeres as the driving force behind all of the associated changes. many of the findings presented are weak correlations that don’t prove anything, but do provide a direction for future exploration.

Written by the scientists who originally discovered telomeres (I think), they go through studies about telomeres and map out what to do and what not to do to keep your telomeres healthy and long. Telomeres are a compound structure at the end of a chromosome. Telomeres get shorter each time a cell copies itself, but the important DNA stays intact. Eventually, telomeres get too short to do their job, causing our cells to stop copying and resulting in cell aging and cell dysfunction. Therefore, telomeres act as the aging clock in every cell.

I really hoped to learn about the biochemistry of telomeres. The book started that way but then slid into self help, meditation, psychological analysis. The latter might be great for some people but lost my interest pretty quickly. A big premise of the book is that mood, attitude, minimization of stress, etc can have a biochemical effect, here in the length of telomeres. Fascinating, but I surely wish it would have been a far smaller part of the book (or even simply an article in Scientific American or similar).

this book has a lot of good ideas for healthy living which will, in turn, help you telomeres stay healthy, that is not shorten too rapidly or even lengthen for a longer (slightly?) longer lifespan ... i found little biological information on telomeres as presented in this book; reference to telomeres with each healthy lifestyle choice was made quite consistently but i am unclear how that tells me about telomeres themselves ... a good book on healthy lifestyle choices; a book short on the biology of telomeres

Telomeres are a part of our cells that protect our DNA. There is now clear research that proves a direct correlation between worn out Telomeres and early aging, and that we can control the healthiness of these through good habits, low stress, and general happiness. The first chapter was interesting, describing the biology behind the Telemores. The rest was just basic guidelines on living a healthy and happy life (and how that impacts our cells). Absolutely nothing new there.

"Groundbreaking" is a little bit of a stretch. Telomeres are fascinating things. However, I felt that this book was mostly fluff, sprinkled with a few tidbits of interesting information here and there. It might have been better if I had the actual book instead of the audio book so that I could easily flip through the boring parts It's mostly common sense, eat healthy, exercise, don't have stress in your life, don't have negative thoughts....oh, and be born with good genes. :)

There is telemore so many times, it was like they were trying to hypnotise me.But the information is new and interesting, the only disappointment is there no miracle cure for anything that can happen to us. The problems have to be resolved the hard way that we already know.Stop Smoking, Stop cussing, stop this and stop thatStart exercising, start early sleeping, early waking and start this and thatAlso you should be rich.

I found the first part of the book interesting in educating me on telomeres and telomerase. I also found the section on the different categories of stress and how to combat them helpful as well. The key to living longer, forever? Exercise, less stress and a plant based diet...... Nothing to be surprised about but knowing that no matter what your age, your lifestyle, there is plenty of things you can do to reverse some of the aging brought upon yourself. Good read.

Interesting concept, but after listening the takeaway wasn’t illuminating. A lot of information that supported a lot of common sense knowledge so I didn’t feel like I learned a lot from this that would inform my actions. As an example, after describing the telomere concept, the authors pointed out that it meant stress was bad for our health and that we should take actions to minimize it or the effects - by eating healthy and exercising. Pretty obvious.

I was surprised and disappointed by the strange mixture of scientific and unscientific information in this book. I'm not opposed to the social sciences, but recommending eating organic, avoiding chemicals (all things are made of chemicals), adopting mindfulness practices, etc. gave certain parts of this book a preachy, unsubstantiated feel. The information on the possible links between telemeres and health were fascinating though.

Tells you all there is to currently know and fear about the deterioration of your teleomeres! Yes, those bits that get worn away as your cells divide again and again. So read it and learn how to delay aging, all the usual warnings and prescriptions for health. I listened to it on audiobook and it goes along well with the two women telling their stories, research, insights, knowlege. Well worth the read.

This book oscillates between science and self-help. I enjoyed the science portion but felt the self-help section muddled the message. Dr Blackburn is clearly an expert in the field with extraordinary insights into Telomeres. The science of telomeres is quite promising and fascinating. However, this book does not properly dive into the research. The self-help advice in this book was fairly basic, Sleep well, eat well, exercise, reduce stress and toxins.

This is a great book. Of course, if you are just looking for easy answers, you will probably not appreciate all the added value compared to every healthy lifestyle handbook.However, what I loved, are all the insights to Elizabeth's research. There are some conclusions, what to do in order to protect your telomeres, however you have here also scientific explanation what is happening to your body on chemical and biological level, and if you will not do this and this, what will be the consequences. So I love that this is not just a list of healthy lifestyle advices, that you can find anywhere, but there is hard scientific explanation behind it.Of course, if you don't care about that, you might be disappointed by this book, as you might have already hear all the advises somewhere else. However, the research background gives this totally new dimension. I will definitely read this again.

Five hours of listening to the audiobook, I believe has entitled me to a review of those 5 hours. The Nobel prize winning data by Elizabeth Blackburn is interesting but I feel that there is no new science to younger living. This gives the same old recommendations. Eat healthy, exercise and don't get stressed out. New title and better editing needed so as not to build up wrong expectations by readers.

I enjoyed this. But a Dr. I know was unimpressed...said it was mostly rehashing already known distributed knowledge.But the idea that stress / deprivation is passed down thru generations...I had heard that it was biologically and I thought it possible, but didn't know how or why. Now I do. Thru shortened telomeres.Really interesting, but it still comes down to balance...eat well, exercise, sleep enough, reduce stress when you can....

Telomere is a protective cup of a DNA. It wears out with years and is responsible for the ageing process. This process can be influenced by how you live. Things that make you happy and healthy slow down the wearing out process. Things like stress, bad food, solitude and alcohol wears out the telomeres faster aging you faster. This is pretty much all what you can take from this book. The book is filled with examples and tips how to sleep better or eat healthier that most of us already know.

A great book for health researcherThe authors simplified advanced and complex scientific knowledge in story telling style that is friendly for almost everyone. Evidence (references) is sufficient for researchers to go deeper while pieces of knowledge are well articulated for general people to follow. Conclusions and action points help readers to recollect take home messages. Recommend this book for every family and every generation.

A very informative book about how our life style and social atmosphere affects our telomere and in general our longevity A great book written by Nobel laureates which in itself made me read the book. It pretty much stresses on living a healthy lifestyle in a good social environment. That way we will have a longer telomere and a better quality of life. This is pretty obvious but they have done a great job in validating their points with solid research data.

I've never heard about telomeres before. The discovery of telomeres is a scientific breakthrough. It leads to a deeper understanding of the processes of aging and how to slow it down. I was amazed by the number of researches that were already made on the topic. The results of most of them are very intriguing. I like the book and recommend it to everyone, especially those who are interested in keeping body and ming in good shape and staying healthy for a long time.

Hokum. No correlation vs causation distinction.Tedious snake oil that never distinguishes between correlation and causation. In other news, children with larger feet are better readers than children with shorter feet (which is true, as they also tend to be older and further along in school). Thus small feet cause reading deficiencies in children, according to the logic of this book.

Basically, everything you know you do is bad for you and you should stop. BUT breaks down the reasons why and how you can make yourself better. Moral of the story is CHILL. Shit happens, relax and don't get bent out of shape over the little things in life. What's the point of worrying all time unless you want to shorten your telomeres and die early. The author does an excellent job making difficult sciency stuff digestible and short anecdotes.

I’ve always had an interest in biology & telomere science. I was fascinated by lobsters & jelly fish regarding how telomerase replicates their DNA over and over again so that they could live for vast amounts of time. Telomeres are repeating nucleotide sequences hanging out on the tips of our chromosomes - they protect the chromosomes but deteriorate with each cell division (isn't aging a bitch?). Plus it's pretty cool to read about telomere research from someone who literally won a Nobel Prize for her work in discovering them.
